marketNews.title: Other hot news to know
marketNews.content:
1. US President Donald Trump said on Friday, 30 May, that he plans to double import tariffs on steel and aluminium to 50%. The announcement came a few hours after Trump accused China of violating an agreement with the US to mutually remove tariffs and restrictions on important mineral trade.
2. BPS recorded that Indonesia's consumer price index (CPI) eased to 1.6% year-on-year in May 2025 (versus 1.95% in April 2025), below the consensus expectation of 1.94% YoY. On a monthly basis, Indonesia experienced deflation of 0.37% MoM (versus 1.17% inflation in April), lower than the consensus forecast of a 0.01% MoM deflation. Core inflation fell to a four-month low of 2.4% YoY (versus 2.5% in April), also below the consensus of 2.5% YoY.
3. S&P Global reported that Indonesia's manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) stood at 47.4 in May 2025 (versus 46.7 in April), indicating a second consecutive month of contraction. New orders contracted at the fastest pace since August 2021 and export sales fell sharply, especially to the United States.
4. China's National Bureau of Statistics reported that China's manufacturing PMI was 49.5 in May 2025 (versus 49 in April), matching consensus expectations and marking a second month of contraction. Output recovered as trade-war tensions eased and the Chinese government continued to stimulate domestic demand. Business confidence improved to 52.5 after reaching a seven-month low of 52.1 in April 2025.
5. Indonesia's trade surplus shrank dramatically to USD 0.15 billion in April 2025 (versus a surplus of USD 2.72 billion in April 2024 and USD 4.33 billion in March 2025), the lowest since April 2020. The decline was driven by a surge in non-energy imports, which rose 21.84% YoY, the highest increase since September 2022, while exports grew only 5.76% YoY, in line with expectations. Over the first four months of 2025, the trade surplus was USD 11.07 billion (versus USD 10.97 billion in the same period of 2024).
6. Commodity-trade analysis firm Kpler reported that Indonesia's thermal coal exports fell 12% YoY in the first five months of 2025 to 188 million tonnes, the lowest level since the first five months of 2022. Exports to China dropped 23% YoY (more than 20 million tonnes) and exports to India fell 14% YoY (more than 6.5 million tonnes). The decline was caused by higher domestic production in those importing countries, reducing their demand for Indonesian coal. Kpler also noted that Indonesia lost sales to eight of its top ten coal-importing countries as global consumer demand and manufacturing activity weakened.
7. Bloomberg reported that Tsingshan Holding Group Co. Ltd. reduced its stainless-steel production in Indonesia's Morowali Industrial Park starting early May 2025. The cut is expected to support stainless-steel prices but could put downward pressure on nickel prices. Both commodities reached five-year lows in April 2025. Tsingshan accounts for almost one-third of global stainless-steel production in 2024, according to Macquarie Group.
8. BPS recorded that foreign tourist arrivals to Indonesia reached 4.33 million during the first four months of 2025, a 5.6% YoY increase, aligning with the government’s 2025 target range of 14-16 million visitors.

marketNews.content: "__Not a wrong analysis, but uncontrolled emotions often cause losses in the stock market." - illusix (https://stockbit.com/illusix)

tickerNews.title: BBRI 4M25: Net Profit (Bank Only) Down 16% YoY
tickerNews.content:
Bank Rakyat Indonesia (BBRI) recorded net profit (bank only) of 3.9 trillion rupiah in April 2025, down 3% year-on-year and 13% month-on-month. This result caused the net profit (bank only) for the first four months of 2025 (4M25) to fall 16% year-on-year to 15 trillion rupiah, below the consensus estimate for consolidated 2025 growth of minus 2.8% year-on-year.
Credit growth remains challenging. Credit disbursement (bank only) for BBRI stayed low at +4.2% year-on-year during 4M25 (versus 3M25: +3.8% YoY, 4M24: +12% YoY), below the management’s consolidated 2025 guidance of +7-9% YoY. As previously noted, the ongoing restructuring of the micro-segment has reduced micro-credit disbursement by 3% YoY in 1Q25.
Net interest income (NII) stagnated, credit cost remains high. Top-line, NII growth was essentially flat at -1% YoY during 4M25. The +4% YoY credit growth did not translate into interest income growth because yields were lower due to the weak micro segment. Non-interest income rose +5% YoY amid operating expenses that jumped +21% YoY. Consequently, pre-provision operating profit (PPOP) fell -8% YoY in 4M25.
Provision expenses fell -28% YoY in April 2025 due to a high-base effect, but rose +2% YoY over 4M25 because of a management provision overlay applied in January 2025. This resulted in cost of credit (CoC) at 3.52% for 4M25 (versus 3.61% in 4M24), higher than the management’s consolidated 2025 guidance.
Key takeaway: Overall, BBRI’s performance in 4M25 is similar to 1Q25, with micro-segment challenges causing NII stagnation and elevated CoC, while rising opex also draws attention.

tickerNews.title: BUMI shareholders approve quasi-reorganization plan
tickerNews.content: BUMI shareholders approved the quasi-reorganization plan in the extraordinary general meeting of shareholders (RUPSLB) on Monday, 2 June. Management said the corporate action will be submitted to the regulator within about two business days after shareholder approval. Previously, BUMI indicated that the impact of the quasi-reorganization would be reflected in the 2Q25 financial statements.

tickerNews.title: MEDC reports net profit of $18 million in 1Q25
tickerNews.content: Medco Energi Internasional reported net profit of 18 million US dollars in 1Q25, down 81% quarter-on-quarter and 76% year-on-year, missing expectations of 5%/5% of the 2025 consensus estimate. The profit decline was mainly driven by a loss from an associate entity of 20 million US dollars (versus a profit of 230 thousand US dollars in 4Q24) due to a sharp increase in loss from Amman Mineral International (AMMN) to 138.8 million US dollars (versus a loss of 80 million US dollars in 4Q24). Operationally, MEDC’s operating profit grew +1.2% quarter-on-quarter to 182 million US dollars, in line with the consensus estimate (24.9% of the 2025 consensus) and above the analyst’s own estimate (27.6% of the 2025 consensus). MEDC recorded declines in oil and gas production of -2.5% and -4.6% quarter-on-quarter respectively, with oil average selling price at 72 US dollars per barrel (down 0.2% QoQ) and gas ASP at 7.1 US dollars per MMBtu (flat QoQ).

tickerNews.title: ADMR shareholders approve 2024 dividend plan
tickerNews.content: Adaro Minerals Indonesia shareholders approved a 2024 dividend distribution of 120 million US dollars, equivalent to 48 rupiah per share assuming an exchange rate of 16,500 rupiah per US dollar. This implies a dividend yield of 4.6% as of Monday, 2 June. The cum-date and payment date have not been announced.

tickerNews.title: INCO awards mining service contracts to PT Pamapersada Nusantara and PT Antareja Mahada Makmur
tickerNews.content: Vale Indonesia awarded mining service contracts to PT Pamapersada Nusantara and PT Antareja Mahada Makmur. The transaction values were not disclosed. PT Pamapersada Nusantara will act as contractor in Block Pomalaa while PT Antareja Mahada Makmur will be contractor in Block Bahodopi 1.

tickerNews.title: INET secures 10 Tbps bandwidth contract with WIFI
tickerNews.content: Kontan reported that Sinergi Inti Andalan Prima secured an international bandwidth sales contract of 10 Tbps with Solusi Sinergi Digital (WIFI) for a ten-year term. INET’s President Director, Muhammad Arif, said the contract will positively affect INET’s performance by providing recurring income, although the total contract value was not disclosed.

tickerNews.title: CFIN to distribute 2024 dividend of ~200 billion IDR
tickerNews.content: Clipan Finance Indonesia will distribute a 2024 dividend of approximately 200 billion rupiah or 50 rupiah per share. This corresponds to a dividend payout ratio of about 93% (versus 0% in 2023) and implies a dividend yield of 12.7% as of Monday, 2 June. The cum-date is on the regular market and negotiation on 10 June 2025, with payment scheduled for 27 June 2025.

tickerNews.title: MTEL plans 5.3 trillion IDR capex in 2025
tickerNews.content: Dayamitra Telekomunikasi’s director, Hendra Purnama, said the company plans to allocate capex of 5.3 trillion rupiah in 2025 (versus 5.6 trillion rupiah allocated in 2024). Of this budget, 2 trillion rupiah will be used for inorganic expansion such as towers, fiber, or other tower-ecosystem assets, while the remainder will support organic growth. MTEL targets an additional 2,500 tenants and 10,000 kilometers of fiber in 2025. In 1Q25, MTEL had 60,259 tenants, 39,593 tower units, and 53,544 km of fiber.

tickerNews.title: IOTF announces acquisition of 49.38% shares by PT Gaia Artha Dinamic
tickerNews.content: Sinergi Makmur announced that PT Gaia Artha Dinamic intends to acquire 49.38% of IOTF’s shares from Alamsyah and Gracia Puspita Suciono. Alamsyah is the chief director and controlling shareholder of IOTF. The transaction value was not disclosed. Upon completion, PT Gaia Artha Dinamic will become the new controlling shareholder of IOTF and will conduct a mandatory tender offer.
